review_title: Dress for success greater London is an amazing charity for women and it one of the best charities I have come across.
pros:
empowering women
making positives changes
success job rate is amazing

pros: It's a small staff which means you do really get to know your coworkers and build relationships with them. The work was not hard and because you know you're making a difference it is so much more fulfilling to do.
cons: Since it's a nonprofit in a rural city you're working with a bare minimum staff. They said my position would be one I could really do from home but they expected me in the office Monday through Friday to open, close, do inventory and answer the phones which was not exactly my job description. Don't get me wrong I didn't mind being there or helping out, I just would have liked to actually have been able to work from home without being guilted every time I needed a day out of office.

pros: Rewarding to work with women from all different backgrounds. It is incredible how far staff and volunteers go to empower the next woman on her journey,

pros: There aren’t any pros when working here.

pros: There are so many different projects to volunteer!
cons: They are not open on Sundays.

review_title: Great mission in theory; in practice, it is an illusion.
pros: Good brand recognition; donors and working women really get behind the mission and it is an easy sell to volunteers.
cons:
The image and the reality are so far from each other that it is very demoralizing for the employees.  Dress for Success Worldwide is extremely disorganized, which makes it difficult for affiliates to maintain good relationships and standards.  One leader at Worldwide is known to be condescending, and disparages Affiliate directors on every conference call -- the directors talk about it openly, but nothing is done to remove the person.  As a result, turnover at Worldwide is high, making it difficult for affiliates to get the support they need.

Also, at least at my urban affiliate, the women being served have generational poverty issues: addiction, incarceration, mental illness -- that cannot be addressed by some self-esteem classes.  The volunteers think they are going to mentor women who are stable, but when they realize the depth of struggles the clients have, they get discouraged.

I agree with other reviewers -- Dress for SUccess has lost focus in their chase of the funding dollars, and has gotten away form their core programs.  Another reviewer said that Dress for Success is trying to provide services that other nonprofits do better and with more resources -- that was absolutely true at my affiliate.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The mission statement has good intentions and there are many women who DFS has helped get back on their feet.
cons:
Everything besides the mission statement. Management is absolutely atrocious in Manhattan, aka Headquarters, aka where they are supposed to be embodying the mission statement the most and lifting up the affiliates to follow, but they only degrade their employees morale, are not inclusive or empowering (yes, I mean you, queer and minority groups), and there are no repercussions when reporting these violations to HR - in fact, HR is a major part of the problem and there is retaliation for speaking up. Incredibly unprofessional and stifling environment. No chance for advancement and you work in fear of losing your job or being targeted if you step out of line with your ideas. 

And don't even get me started on the pay - some employees qualifying for food stamps while the CEO makes almost a half a million a year. Shameful. 

If I could give it less than 1 star I would. I highly do not recommend applying here until some major reform takes place within management. Have lunch with a few employees before accepting a position to see how it really is.

review_title: People are Great, policies are not
job_title: Executive Assistant to Chief Executive Officer in Harrisburg, PA
pros: Meeting so many wonderful women (and men) dedicated to helping unemployed women find their own strengths, their style, their assets, their voice and their confidence. The volunteers who come are just exceptional human beings and the staff are talented, big-hearted and hard working women.
cons: Employees are NOT empowered, Human Resource  policies are at the whim of each affiliate, "full-time with benefits" does not mean much, World Wide DFS offers no greater pool to empower their own workers with healthcare, bereavement, life insurance or retirement plans. Hard to write and talk about empowerment all day when you see fellow workers struggle to make their own lives work and get called out for questioning bad leadership decisions. High turn over is the result. Fiefdoms are not what this organization should be about!

review_title: Need to practice what you preach
pros: A mission that is easy to embrace. On the front lines and on a basic level, women are being empowered to start or restart their careers. They are given self confidence and some very basic, but important tools for to walk into an interview and make a great impression on a potential employer.
cons:
Employees start their career at Dress for Success inspired by the mission and ready to make a difference, but they leave disempowered and disillusioned as the leadership doesn't practice what it preaches.
- Collaboration and new ideas are not welcome.
- Heirarchy and status quo are celebrated.
- Innovation and constructive criticism are stiffled.
- The professionalism that is the core of the client message is non-existent in the employee culture.
- Technology that could take them to the forefront of the industry is ignored and/or set at the bottom of the priority list.
- Questionable spending practices of grants from major funding sources ensure that a minimal percentage of the money actually benefits clients directly or builds a solid infrastructure based on strategic planning.

review_title: Not at all what I expected
pros:
1) Their clients genuinely appreciate the assistance they receive.  Although no hard-skills programs or job placement services are offered, sometimes inspiration can be a powerful tool.
2) Strong brand-name recognition.
cons:
1) Favoritism is rampant.  Promotions and being treated courteously by supervisors are rewards based on an employee's membership in whatever the favored clique is and brown nosing.
2) Many of their employees are demoralized.  Past and current employees who are unafraid of hard work and have marketable skills have been degraded to the point that they essentially gave up.
3) There is no human resources department.  People fear for their jobs and dare not report legitimate concerns.
4) For an organization that champions women's economic empowerment, it is unfortunate that several employees have difficulty making ends meet or saving for their own futures.

pros: The mission! I truly feel like the intent is to empower women through the clothing they provide.
cons:
Where do I start. 

First off they lost sight of the mission and became more about the money. 

At the branch I was at they are supposed to raise $500,000 and help only 1600 clients a year. The math doesn't add up. They started to operate far more corporate than as a nonprofit. 

Their "developmental tools" are not that at all. Clients come to get clothes and that is it. There is no true tracking of client success and I feel statistics are fabricated. 

The staff is over worked for little pay except for the direcTors. Who are salaried and take credit for the hourly workers jobs. 

High and I mean high staff turnover. And very low unit morale. 

The headquarters staff are very rude! The office email language is very very aggressive. Not a team at all. 

No relationships with the affiliates whatsoever so The Whole international thing is a fluke. 

Big ideas and no follow through or execution plans.

review_title: Job was Amazing when you worked with Clients
pros: I loved working there because I was able to help clients out. Meeting new people was amazing
cons:
Hours were cut short sometimes. There was days we were not open when we should have been. Supervisor was always gone and I was never able to get in contact with her when it was very important. She did not seem like she really cared about the clients it was just about getting things done fast instead of focusing on the clients. 

I did a pop in at BC for a class. Then put in my hours for work for being there. She got upset and thought I did it voluntarily, I spend my gas and time to go up there to bring people into our door. Pay was very low!

pros: Mission sounds great, in reality not...working at DFS you find it very fulfilling to help women in prove their life's that's the best part of working for DFS.
cons: There is no work life balance, staff is treated with disrespect, you work long tireless hours,  employees turn on each other when the pressure get high, volunteers are not appreciated, you work in fear of loosing your job, the list goes on.

review_title: Powerful brand with real impact but very poor internal management and organizational culture
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Dress for Success makes a positive difference in the lives of disadvantaged women. They do successfully empower women through their services as stated in their mission.
cons: Employees are generally not afforded the same respect, opportunities for growth and empowerment that is given to clients. The challenge is senior management and their inability to create an organizational culture that is transparent, values driven, respectful, communicative and collaborative.

review_title: Heart warming work with crazy leadership
pros: Really wonderful way to help women gain confidence and get employment. Unique method of tying everyday citizens into the employment sector through volunteerism and donations to positively impact the unemployed. Good mix of city, state and local efforts. Franchises make you feel you are working for a small mom and pop versus an international company. Young enough that they are still pretty jazzed up about anything they do . . lots of enthusiasm for the brand. Many clients are absolutely appreciative of your help and understand the gift and help they are being given is essentially life changing. Those clients will bring tears of happiness to your eyes and will go on to become very productive in their new job. The volunteers are diverse, educated, hard working, well intentioned and a delight to work with.
cons: The focus of the organization changed a few years ago and their was some infighting at the corporate level which resulted in the founder leaving. They focus now as much on job prep and classes as on suiting. Well, there are a ton of job prep NPO's and for-profits that do it better. They were losing their niche, volunteers got frustrated and so did employees. Simultaneously, they rolled out sub-par branding which required investment dollars from all the franchises and it got a bit messy. Besides the corporate vs franchise troubles, you get the government funding troubles (can you get in contact with an important source when the government is furloughed?). Then there is a type of client attitude you run into daily, "I don't care that I just got out of jail (or rehab, or probation . . ), You can't tell me I have to wear a suit to an interview. I don't want to make a resume. I am only here because someone is forcing me to be here. Just sign this so I can get my check. That's a butt ugly suit and It looks like my grandma would wear it (brand new Jones of New York!)." They start to give you a dim view of the education and parenting levels in America. Don't forget it is a non-profit and you are paid accordingly. Also, there is no one to assist you if the franchise owner is a tyrant. You basically call it like it is and start looking for another job. If you are considering a job here you should definitely ask the person you interview with: "How many people have held this position in the last two years and why did they leave?"

review_title: Dress for Success is a wonderful company that strives to empower women, but it is often mismanaged.
pros: It was wonderful to be a part of a caring team and work with the extraordinary women who came in for suitings, programming, and more.
cons: It was somewhat disorganized in terms of its management. Employees would often come and go, and decisions seemed to be influenced by politics, rather than what is best for the clients.

pros: The mission is admirable and at the most basic level, clients are given hope and treated with respect and dignity.
cons: The services given by program staff and volunteers does not translate to the employees. Employees are not given creative license, are expected to do what they are told without questioning authority, no matter how nonsensical the plan may be. Training and direction are virtually non-existent and reporting is a farce. The organization bows to potential funders and neglects to excel at  it's core mission - to empower women.

pros: Amazing people working together to do amazing things. For a non profit they had good compensation and they want to see you grow. Best first job experience I could have asked for
cons: Small office with limited resources, but that is expected with any non profit organization. They know how to work well and efficiently to counteract the limitations

review_title: Great cause and that's where it ends.
pros: The mission is worthy and the majority of the clients are wonderful to work with and really show their appreciation.
cons: CONSTANT turnover at every level, incredibly poor communication at every level, salaries are dismal even for nonprofit, no support or encouragement to grow within the organization, incredibly disorganized with many incompetent directors and c-level staff, no technological advances seemingly in the last decade.

pros: The mission is a worthy one and they have good name recognition.
cons: There is a lack of focus and serious lack of leadership. Wages are so low that some full time employees qualify for food stamps. Even at a non-profit, that should not happen! The low salaries make it difficult to attract and keep good people, and that damages the effectiveness of the organization.

pros: Love the mission, love the people, the office is a really nice place to come into work, everyone is supporting your goals in and out of the office
cons: Sometimes boring on a slow day, a lot of repetitive tasks that aren't super challenging intellectually

pros:
-Enthusiastic and nice women to work with
-Empowering women everyday is an amazing feeling
-You get a sneak peek and opportunity for early purchase on pop up shop items
-Treated with respect and feel like coworkers really care about you
-Fun workplace
cons: I wish my internship was able to turn into a full time position but due to budget restrictions, an expanding staff isn't always an option. Overall amazing experience!

review_title: Great Mission- Not So Great Leadership
pros: Working with women to improve their lives is rewarding and challenging (in a good way).  Networking with different agencies proves useful even outside of the job.
cons: Salary low for the amount of energy needed for the job.  Poor leadership in local chapter.  Small staff- employees need to wear MANY hats and are not compensated for it.

pros: You get to help others feel good by offering them services they may not be able obtain elsewhere.  Giving someone else a boost of confidence makes you feel like you contributed.
cons: Management is terrible and dysfunctional.  They operate by leading with fear, and do not invest in your professional development whatsoever.  Management speaks to you in a disrespectful and condescending manner. They also want nothing to do with your creativity or originality.

review_title: Mission is good in theory but not the reality
pros: The theory of the mission which is to educate, enhance, encourage, and empower sounds good.
cons:
Management did not know how to manage or communicate effectively. Goal setting seemed unheard of! I was told that my position as Program Assistant "was being made up as we go along". Needless to say this is frustrating when your boss doesn't even know how to lead or direct. I tried on several occasions to make suggestions but they were ignored and disregarded. I was verbally disrespected and even called out of my name in front of staff and volunteers which brought me to tears on two occasions. Staff eventually became disrespectful of one another and volunteers as well. 
Clients were constantly complaining about needing REAL help in obtaining work. Clients in the Professional Women's Group were given clothes every week just for showing up! Needless to say this results in the ladies just coming to go shopping for free every week. Enabling much? 

Under pressure of "not being a team player" and losing my job, I was pretty much strong-armed into working 40+ hours a week, regularly working 12 hour shifts but the Executive Director refused to pay me for the additional hours. As a result, my family suffered (I'm a single mom and on the bus line) and I had to halt furthering my education because I was failing so bad from missing classes and assignments. Educating, Enhancing, Encouraging, and Empowering huh?! The Manager of Workforce Development ended up quitting before I did. Good for her! Also, there is no room or opportunity of advancement. 

The core of the business seems to revolve around funding and donors instead of serving the client. Only 12 hours a week max dedicated to serving clients. The remaining hours were for fund raising events and parties. Clothing and toy donations were taken to the Executive Director's church to be distributed! I know because I was made to carry the bags into the church. 

Staff was constantly in staff meetings with the Executive Director. As a result, work couldn't get done and  numerous phone calls from donors, clients, and agencies got missed. Complaints were made. 

Even though there were only 3 employees to pay, I barely made a living wage! According to Glassdoor,  the average Program Administrator makes 46, 000 a year. I did even make half of that! 

After a year with this company I finally came to my senses and found a new job and enrolled back in school!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The mission is one that we all could agree is pretty awesome.  It is sad that those of us who wanted to do good work where abused and dreaded coming into work.
cons: Everything else.  The management is nasty to employees, they talk and laugh about people and don't care about anything except looking like they do good work.

review_title: CEO and upper management need complete upgrade
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Mission is amazing and women that are served need the organization to exist
cons: There are too many to list: - upper management and CEO are completely rude and dont care about their staff. Where is the board? Aren't they supposed to know what is going on? They loose staff every few months due to the CEO's inability to run a business. They will never succeed if she is still there unfortunately.

review_title: Great mission and programs, organization runs very lean

cons: Organization runs very lean, sometimes at the expense of productivity and outcomes. Uses volunteers for many staff functions. Entrepreneurial but sometimes slow to move.

pros: - you get to help so many women, and it is so rewarding being able to first hand help a woman be confident to go interview and dress for the career of her dreams
cons: - lots of clothing to choose from, sometimes difficult to work with some of the clients who come in

pros: Wonderful place to volunteer and help women in area.  I do career coaching, speaking for organization and mentoring
cons: No pay except for satisfaction.  Not enough feedback for how well individual clients do once the coaching is over

pros: It was a Contract position with flexible hours. The programs helped unemployed women to get back into employment.
cons: They moved to a new location which a little far out and they budget is limited.

job_title: Assistant Boutique Manager in Woodbridge, VA
pros: We empower women to achieve economic independence by providing a network of support, professional attire and the development tools to help women thrive in work and in life.
cons: We are a nonprofit organization and need funding by grants that are hard to come by.

pros: Great colleagues working together in a positive atmosphere, sharing a mission to support other women re-entering the workforce.  Flexible schedule.
cons: All positions are volunteer (except for the Director), however, this is a great place to volunteer and give back to the community.

pros: The empowering of women and helping the community was very rewarding. Also engaging with the clients and seeing them smile.
cons:
Management. They did not acknowledge employees, interns and volunteers. They give more importance to the clients without seeing that many of the people who work for them also need empowerment and inspiration. 
Horrible policies and extremely disorganized.

pros: Very great speakers!Very professional speakers that are doing the mock interviews.
cons: The staff is extremely unprofessional.Mentioned my housing situation to a potential job opening.I felt i was humiliated in my interview although i was offered the position but my housing situation is a confidential situation that should not have been disclosed.Staff said we talked to much.Very Very unprofessional approach to clients.

review_title: Management does not practice what they preach
pros: Great seeing the lives of the women change
cons: The mission of the organization is to empower women but management does not empower the staff at all. Change or new ideas are not welcomed. Favoritism runs this organization.

review_title: Great organization but can be chaotic at times

- Staff and volunteers are very passionate about the organization and the work they do
cons: - Can be chaotic when there are not enough staff and volunteers

pros: Helping woman transition into the workplace
cons: Boutique could be more organized and would be great if there were career opportunities for who wish to start career with the organization instead of volunteering

pros: Their heart is in the right place
cons: They need to keep better statistics regarding those they serve, so they have real numbers showing real successes

pros: Extremely great mission.  Off Christmas week. Great financial literacy program for participates of  DFS  program.

pros: A wonderful organization for an important cause.  Motivating women to gain economic independence for herself and change her life.
